name: Pompeii
fun_fact: Fun fact: The wood-fired pizza ovens used in Naples today are nearly identical to the ancient Roman ovens excavated at Pompeii! A painting of ancient Roman flatbread was even found at the ruins. Modern Neapolitan pizza-making was honored with UNESCO 'intangible cultural heritage' status in 2017, connecting 2,000 years of pizza history.

hero_dishes.name: Pizza Margherita
hero_dishes.description: The archetypal Neapolitan pizza: San Marzano tomatoes, buffalo mozzarella, fresh basil, and olive oil on wood-fired dough, representing the Italian flag (red, white, green)
hero_dishes.origin_story: Modern pizza evolved in Naples's poorer areas in the late 18th-early 19th century when adding tomatoes to flatbread became a sensation. By 1807, Naples had 54 pizzerias. Legend says Raffaele Esposito created the Margherita in 1889 for Queen Margherita, though the pizza already existed before. In 2010, it received STG (SpecialitÃ  Tradizionale Garantita) designation
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Trammiere (2.9km from Pompeii) - highly acclaimed for exceptional Neapolitan pizzas like Margherita, Napoletana, and Bufalina. Also Pizzeria Orlando near the archaeological site entrance for wood-fired pizzas

hero_dishes.name: Authentic Neapolitan Pizza with DOP Ingredients
hero_dishes.description: Pizza baked 60-90 seconds at minimum 800Â°F in stone igloo-shaped wood-fire ovens, using only San Marzano tomatoes from Mount Vesuvius and either Mozzarella di Bufala Campana or Fior di Latte di Agerola
hero_dishes.origin_story: True DOP San Marzano tomatoes only grow at the bottom of Mount Vesuvius, 9km east of Naples, on volcanic plains. Buffalo mozzarella comes from water buffaloes brought by Normans to Naples from India for hard physical labor
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Ristorante President Pompei (Michelin-starred, near Madonna di Pompeii Sanctuary) - Chef Paolo Gramaglia since 1993 blends traditional and innovative Italian dishes

hero_dishes.name: Pasta alla Genovese
hero_dishes.description: Traditional Neapolitan slow-cooked onion and meat sauce served with pasta - despite its name, this is a Naples specialty, not from Genoa
hero_dishes.origin_story: A cornerstone of Campania cuisine, this dish requires hours of slow cooking to caramelize the onions into a rich, sweet sauce
hero_dishes.where_to_find: La Bettola del Gusto - family-owned restaurant specializing in traditional Neapolitan cuisine with cozy atmosphere and rustic decor

hero_dishes.name: Traditional Campanian Antipasti
hero_dishes.description: Local charcuterie, buffalo mozzarella, authentic breads, and traditional Campanian dishes featuring San Marzano tomatoes
hero_dishes.origin_story: Campania's cuisine is one of the richest and most varied in Italy, world-famous for Neapolitan pizza, buffalo mozzarella, and San Marzano tomatoes. The volcanic soil of Vesuvius creates unique flavors
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Casina dell'Aquila inside the archaeological park - 'Pizza, Pasta & More' offers tastings of local products in the inner courtyard with wines and cheeses

signature_drinks.name: Limoncello
signature_drinks.description: Sweet lemon liqueur made from Amalfi Coast lemons, served ice-cold as a digestif
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Served in chilled glasses after meals throughout Campania. The Amalfi Coast lemons are famous worldwide for their intense fragrance and flavor

signature_drinks.name: Local Campanian Wines
signature_drinks.description: Wines from the volcanic slopes of Mount Vesuvius, including Lacryma Christi (Tears of Christ) and Greco di Tufo
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Paired with meals at restaurants near Pompeii. The volcanic soil creates distinctive mineral flavors in the wines

food_culture_notes: Inside the archaeological park, visitors can sample authentic Campanian dishes and artisanal ice cream at the CafÃ© & Wine Bar
Campania is world-famous for iconic desserts like Rum baba and sfogliatella
Na Pasta near Pompeii serves affordable specialty pasta (gnocchi, spaghetti, lasagna) for around 7 euros - ideal for budget travelers
La Gare (220m from Pompeii) offers a serene escape from touristy hustle with Italian cuisines including pizza, seafood, and Mediterranean specialties
For fine dining, Hortus Restaurant in a historic building offers tasting menus showcasing the best of Italian cuisine with fresh, seasonal ingredients
Ancient Romans at Pompeii ate flatbreads painted on murals, and used ovens excavated at the ruins that look identical to modern pizza ovens
Pizza is so important that Neapolitan pizza-making received UNESCO intangible cultural heritage status in 2017

unique_modern: DOP protected ingredients from volcanic soil
